messageBody:
Hi Leslie,

thats a real historical question ,-)

I do not have an JDK 1.1.8 available, to do any testing. But, I did a port
of JUnit 3.8.1 for a very small virtual machine, called leJOS [1]. I called
this port leJOSUnit [2], which is OpenSouce, you can download to have a look
inside. leJOS is based on -target 1.1 byte code, so a √ç am definitely sure,
that leJOSUnit is running on JDK 1.1.

The main thing to be done was avoid any Java reflection. I do not known,
since when all the required reflection capabilities for JUnit 3.8.1 have
been intoduced in J2SE.

In leJOSUnit, the mechanism to setup a TestCase is very simple. Lets see an
example for a TestCase:

public class OneTest extends TestCase {
public OneTest(String name) {
super(name);
}
public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
suite.addTest(new OneTest("testOne"));
suite.addTest(new OneTest("testTwo"));
return suite;
}
protected void runTest() throws Throwable {
if ("testOne".equals(getName())) {
testOne();
} else if ("testTwo".equals(getName())) {
testTwo();
} else {
fail();
}
}
public void testOne() {
// ...
}
public void testTwo() {
// ...
}
}

So, the basic idea is to implement the runTest() and dispatch with a static
approach. A TestSuite can be implemented the known way:

public class AllTests {
public static void main(String[] args) {
// put here a runner for your embedded platform, or a
junit.textui.runner when a console is available
// ... lejosunit.rcxui.TestRunner.main(suite());
}

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
suite.addTest(OneTest.suite());
suite.addTest(TwoTest.suite());
return suite;
}
}

This is only a hint for which direction to look for. What kind of error do
you have ? Did you try to run the JUnit test suite against itself ?

Bye, Jochen

[1] http://www.lejos.org
[2] http://lejosunit.sourceforge.net
